The electrochemical oxidation reaction of small molecules (EORSM) has attracted extensive attention due to its advantages such as mild operating conditions, high conversion efficiency, good selectivity and environmental friendliness. Moreover, with relatively fast reaction kinetics and low theoretical thermodynamic equilibrium potential, EORSM is expected to replace anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The coupling of EORSM at anode with hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at cathode could realize multiple targets including high-value chemicals production, pollutant degradation and efficient hydrogen production. Black phosphorus-based nanocomposites are supposed as a promising EORSM electrocatalyst due to their adjustable electronic structure, large specific surface area, high carrier mobility and active lone pair electrons. Apart from that, transition metal phosphates (TMPs) are also widely used for EORSM because of their abundant active sites, strong electrical conductivity and adjustable component structure. This mini review briefly summarizes the recent progress of EORSM including alcohol oxidation, urea oxidation and hydrazine oxidation over BP-based nanocomposites or TMPs. In addition, possible challenges and research directions are also discussed for inspiring people to optimize EORSM using BP-based nanocomposites and ™Ps. Graphical abstract Black phosphorus-based nanocomposites and transition metal phosphates for electrocatalytic oxidation of small molecules. Image, graphical abstract Key Words Black phosphorus Electrocatalytic oxidation Small molecule Transition metal phosphates Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction To deal with the energy crisis and environmental pollution problems, renewable energy must be developed. Clean hydrogen fuel is expected as an ideal substitute to fossil fuels [1]. Among these methods for hydrogen production, electrocatalytic water electrolysis has drawn more attentions due to its mild synthesis condition and environmental friendliness. Electrocatalytic water electrolysis involves two half reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) carries out at cathode and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) happens at anode. Different from HER, the four-electron transfer process of OER results in slow reaction kinetics and a high theoretical potential (1.23 V vs. RHE) for OER [2,3]. Such a large overpotential greatly diminishes the conversion efficiency of water electrolysis [4,5]. To produce hydrogen with high energy efficiency, researchers have explored electrooxidation of small organic molecules with low-overpotential to replace anodic OER. For example, Bambagioni et al. [6] found that the electrooxidation of renewable alcohols for hydrogen production could achieve a 67% conversion efficiency compared with conventional water electrolysis under the same condition. In this mini review, several electrochemical oxidation reaction of small molecules (EORSM) for hydrogen production are reviewed. In addition, EORSM has other advantages. Electrochemical urea oxidation and hydrazine oxidation could avoid potential environmental pollution from direct urea and hydrazine emission. Electrochemical alcohol oxidation reaction generates chemical products such as acetate or acetaldehyde with strong practicality for chemical industry. In industrial production processes, the synthesis of oxidation products is performed via a sequence of energy-intensive and high-temperature processes. Furthermore, precious metal catalysts and dedicated infrastructure are generally required, leading to high costs and large amounts of catastrophic chemical reagents. Compared with that, electrochemical synthesis reactions require less energy and lower temperature. Therefore, the EORSM not only can be coupled with HER for hydrogen production, but also provide other benefits. [7–9]. Since 2014, the two-dimensional black phosphorus (BP) nanosheets have been widely used in the fields of electrocatalysis and photoelectrocatalysis [10–13]. As a new promising OER electrocatalyst, BP based materials show excellent properties such as controllable electronic structure, large specific surface area, high carrier mobility, and lone pair electrons [14–19]. Moreover, the advantage of using BP as electrocatalyst lies in the following aspects: (1) BP is easily to form into phosphide by coordination with metal due to its lone pair electrons. (2) Metal nanoparticles can be effectively dispersed on BP, which supports a large specific surface area, resulting in a high number of active sites. (3) BP exhibits a strong adsorption capacity for water molecules, facilitating the formation of hydroxyl groups and intermediates [20]. For transition metal phosphides (TMPs), metal cations as proton receptors and non-metallic phosphorus as hydride receptors play an important part in hydroxyl adsorption and O2 desorption, respectively. Therefore, TMPs are potential efficient eleccatalysts for water splitting [21,22]. Here, phosphorus can increase the atomic spacing, weaken the interaction between metals, cause d-band contraction, and enhance electrical conductivity of the TMPs [23]. This review provides a concise summary of the recent advancements in the oxidation reactions of small molecules over BP-based nanocomposites or TMPs. What's more, the structure-activity relationship of BP-based nanocomposites or TMPs towards EORSM is systematically investigated. The schematic illustration of this review content is shown in Fig. 1 . In the final part, the review discusses potential challenges and research directions for EORSM over BP-based nanocomposites and TMPs. 2 Application for electrocatalytic oxidation of small molecules 2.1 Alcohol oxidation reaction With the rapid consumption of limited fossil fuels and growing energy needs, search for renewable energy as well as green energy is urgent [24,25]. Solar energy is considered as a promising clean energy with the characteristics of high theoretical power generation rate and environmental friendliness [26,27]. However, the fluctuation of natural solar energy limited their application. Different from that, direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFCs), which converts chemical energy directly into electric energy, drawn more attentions due to the abundance of ethanol sources and high theoretical energy density. The challenge of slow reaction rate and poor stability in ethanol oxidation reaction needs to be addressed in order to promote the widespread use of DEFCs. Numerous studies have demonstrated that, palladium-based catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity, low cost and excellent resistance to carbon monoxide toxicity in alkaline medium [28–30]. By improving the stability of nanoparticles, other metals or non-metals are doped to adjust their electronic structure, which becomes the focus of current research on material synthesis strategies, and the catalytic activity of the target can be further improved [31,32]. Zhang et al. [20] designed and synthesized a type of heterogeneous Pd3P/BP catalyst, which exhibits high catalytic activity and stability for EOR at low temperatures (Fig. 2 ). Firstly, Pd2+ ions are firmly bound to the BP to from the BP/Pd2+ complex. Later, nanoparticles with an average size of 6.2 nm were obtained on the surface of black phosphorus using a solvothermal strategy. The synergistic effect between Pd3P NPs and BP boost EOR activity and stability of Pd3P/BP compared to Pd3P + BP (physical mixture), Pd3P, and BP (Fig. 3 ). For Pd/graphene catalyst towards alcohol oxidation, introduction of heteroatoms such as nitrogen, sulfur, phosphorus, etc. can change the electronic structure of graphene. Moreover, introducing transition metal oxides (MnO2, CeO2, TiO2, etc.) into the Pd/graphene are extremely useful strategy for enhancing the electrocatalytic activity by adsorbing more *OH in alkaline solution. With direct band gap, BP exhibits adjustable carrier mobility and high hole migration rate [33–38]. Recent research have shown that the generation of *OH and stripping of active intermediates depend on the introduction of 2D BP [39]. Wu et al. [40] proposed a new method for the rational preparation of graphene/BP heterostructures to enhance the EOR activity of Pd (Fig. 4 ). BP, potassium hydroxide (potassium hydroxide) and activated graphene (AG) structure were combined by ball grinding. The obtained Pd/AG-BP hybrids show ultra-high electrochemical activity for the EOR under alkaline conditions (Fig. 5 ). The AG-BP heterostructures with P-C bond linkage can facilitate the generation of adsorbed OH species (OHads) for the oxidation of carcinomic intermediates. The substitution of OER by alcohol oxidation for hydrogen production has been proven to be significant in studies. However, it has also been found that the separation and purification of alcohol oxidation products is still a problem to be solved. In addition, the competition between OER and alcohol oxidation reaction still exists at high current density, which greatly limits its application in industry. Peruzzini et al. [41] found that the strong interaction exist between the metal and the 2D BP carriers as confirmed by scanning transmission electron microscopy. The interaction was quantitatively characterized by X-ray absorption spectroscopy, and the short distance of Pd-P was found to be only 2.26 Å, indicating that the interaction is a covalent Pd-P coordination bond. The change of the electronic environment of Pd atoms depends on the synergistic effect between Pd nanoparticles and phosphorus atoms. At the same time, the change of metal electronic structure has a favorable influence on the adsorption energy and activation barrier of interfacial reactants or intermediates in electrochemical catalysis. Yu et al. [42] synthesized the platinum/BP catalyst. The characterization results suggest that BP has a strong activation effect on the platinum through the synergistic effect between the metal and the supporter. When platinum is bonded to phosphorus, the center of its d band is optimized to the Fermi level, providing suitable energy for electrocatalytic HER intermediates. A large number of literature researches support the idea that loading metal on 2D BP nanosheets can enhance the reactivity of alcohol oxidation. For AOR, BP based materials show the following advantages: (1) Benefiting from the large specific surface area of BP, metal nanoparticles with high dispersion and more active sites can be obtained, which could make full use of metal catalysts. (2) Metal atoms can interact strongly with the lone pair electrons of BP, thus this will optimize the d-band center of metal atoms and enhance the electrocatalytic performance for AOR. (3) BP shows a good adsorption capacity toward water, which promotes the formation of OHads and the stripping of intermediates COads. (4) The strong coordination bond between BP and the metal will promote the separation and agglomeration of the metal, thus enhancing the stability of the catalyst. However, BP nanosheets are easy to be oxidized, which greatly limits their application as two-dimensional material supports. The inhibition of oxidative degradation of BP can be achieved by surface modification or doping. For instance, tannin (TA) or polyurethane-functionalized BP nanosheets can enhance stability after prolonged exposure to oxygen and water. In fact, the lone electron coordination of phosphorus atoms is affected by the change of group or doping element, which will lead to the loss of the inherent structural advantages of supporter. In general, the preparation of two-dimensional BP nanosheets with high stability, large specific surface area and high performance is particularly important for the development of processing technology. Min et al. [39] synthesized a new anatase titanium dioxide/black phosphorus hybrid (ATN-BP) as the supporter for palladium nanoparticles towards EOR (Fig. 6 ). Under the protection of argon gas, BP nanosheets and ATN are prepared directly by ball milling, leading to the formed bonding of P-O-Ti. The construction of ATN-BP not only improves electrolyte permeability and electron transport, but also promotes the stripping of intermediates through the synergistic effect of Pd and ATN-BP. The P impurity occupies the cation site (Ti4+) in the ATN lattice, forming into phosphorus-doped ATN. When ATN-BP is used to support Pd NPs, the resulted Pd/ATN-BP hybrids with heterogeneous interfaces of Pd, BP and ATN show significant electrical activity and durability in alkaline media. After 3600 s of testing, the Pd/ATN-BP catalyst exhibits good durability and stability (Fig. 7 ). Designing and synthesizing heterogeneous materials could make the best use of BP-based materials as metal supporters. Non noble metal phosphide is also promising electrocatalyst for alcohol oxidation. In a Lewis acid-base environment, the introduction of metal ions (such as Fe, Cu, Co, Mn) to BP enhances the ability of d electron transfer between transition metal elements, thus affecting their catalytic performance [43]. As shown for molybdenum phosphide, its exhibits good electronic properties and high conductivity because of enhanced compositions and structures [44]. 2.2 Urea oxidation reaction With a low theoretical potential (0.37 V vs. RHE), anodic urea oxidation reaction has been widely concerned and used to improve hydrogen production efficiency [57,58]. Additionally, urea oxidation as a direct fuel cell also provides a significant function for wastewater purification [59,60]. However, the anodic UOR process involves 6e– transfer (CO(NH2)2 + 6OH− → N2 + 5H2O + CO2 + 6e−), highly active and affordable electrocatalysts are required to boost the efficiency [61]. While Pt/C and IrO2 have been demonstrated good activity for UOR, their low earth content and high-cost limit their scope of application [62–65]. Therefore, the development of high efficiency electrocatalyst is of great significance to improve the efficiency of hydrogen production through UOR. In recent years, researchers have found that nickel-based catalysts, including nickel oxides, hydroxides, and phosphides, exhibit high catalytic activity for UOR [46,66,67]. Among them, nickel-based phosphides with low cost, adjustable element composition, redox characteristics, show a good development for UOR [68,69]. Transition metal phosphates (TMPs) have drawn more attentions because of their low cost and abundant sources [45–48]. Besides, they also show specific properties such as high stability, adjustable central metal valence state, and appropriate binding energy of intermediates in catalytic reactions. Inspired by highly active centers of layered dihydroxide, dimetallic phosphates (e.g. NiCoP [49], CoFeP [50], NiFeP [51–53]) enhance electrocatalytic performance through synergistic interaction between the two active metal components. Moreover, the oxyphosphates [54–56] exhibit good catalytic activity on account of phosphorus-oxygen interaction, which would greatly increase the number of active sites. The generated M-P and M-O bonds are benefitting for regulating the electron configuration, optimizing the adsorption/desorption free energy of intermediates, and improving the reaction activity [31]. Lu et al. [70] successfully loaded ZIF-67 on the surface of wood fiber by using the anchoring effect of forest residues and wood fiber. Subsequently, a P-doped carbonized wood fiber supported P, N co-doped carbon-coated CoP nanoparticle composite electrocatalyst (CoP@PNC/PCWF) was synthesized by simultaneous carbonization phosphatizing treatment for efficient urea catalytic oxidation (Fig. 8 ). The results show that the unique coating structure of the CoP@PNC/PCWF provides the electrocatalyst with good conductivity, structural stability, and a large number of exposed active sites. Meanwhile, doped carbon can induce more defect structures of carbon and regulate the electronic structure of the CoP@PNC surface. The electrochemical test results show that the CoP@PNC/PCWF catalyst exhibits outstanding catalytic performance for UOR, achieving a current density of 50 mA cm−2 with a voltage of only 1.32 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. 9 ). In addition, when urea-assisted electrolytic hydrogen production is carried out with CoP@PNC/PCWF as the anode, a current density of 50 mA cm−2 can be achieved with only 1.5 V working voltage (Fig. 10 ). This work offers an idea for the development of low-cost, urea-assisted, energy-saving electrocatalysts for hydrogen production using forest residues, without the need of nickel. The morphological regulation of nanomaterials can increase the number of active sites, so the catalytic activity in the reaction can be further improved [23,71]. There are various morphologies of oxygen phosphating catalysts (for example nanoparticles [17], nanosheets [24], nanotubes [25]). Their special porosity and large specific surface area made them serve as an effective water cracking catalyst. Good electrical conductivity, more active site exposure, and larger specific surface area are the unique advantages of ultra-thin two-dimensional materials, therefore, they are widely used in catalysis, electronics, energy, and other fields [26]. Oxygen phosphating catalysts also show good catalytic activity due to the interaction of phosphorus and oxygen, which will greatly increase the active site. The symbiotic metal-P bond and metal-O bond are beneficial to regulate the electronic structure of the intermediates, optimize the adsorption/desorption free energy of the intermediates, and thus improve the overall water decomposition performance. In-situ conversion of doped nitrogen and multicomponent metal by ion substitution is another method to change catalytic activity of the composites. Yang et al. [72] synthesized ultra-thin bimetal nanoparticles (CoNiOP/NF) as a multifunction catalyst for HER, OER and UOR (Fig. 11 ). Theoretical calculations and experimental studies both confirm that electron transfer between the metal center and the interface anion is conducive to accelerating the reaction, optimizing the adsorption of intermediates. Therefore the electrocatalytic activity has been greatly improved. Using UOR instead of OER, it needs 1.42 V to achieve current density of 50 mA cm−2. CoNiOP displays the excellent electrocatalytic activity and remarkable durability, attributed to the ultrathin nanosheet, adjustable chemical composition and three-dimensional porous conductive supporter. Constructing planar heterostructures, increasing the number of edge active sites, enhancing the surface area of two-dimensional nanosheets, and cutting the transport distance between electrons and ions are important way to improve the catalytic activity (Fig. 12 ). That is conductive to regulating the electronic structure and optimizing the adsorption/desorption free energy of intermediates, so that it displays good performance. Liu et al. [73] successfully synthesized Ni2P nanosheets through phosphorylating β-Ni (OH)2 nanosheets for electrocatalytic urea oxidation (Fig. 13 ). Ni2P nanosheets effectively improve the OER and UOR performance compared to β-Ni (OH)2 nanosheets. The Ni2P nanosheets also exhibit relatively good UOR performance with onset potential of 1.33 V and peak current of 95.47 mA cm−2 at 1.6 V (Fig. 14 ). The accelerated proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) process resulted from (PO4)3 promotes the formation of NiOOH; therefore, it results in a lower initial potential for the OER and UOR compared to β-Ni (OH)2. For nickel-based catalysts, in-situ generated NiOOH are considered as the main reactive species for OER and UOR [74–77]. The amount of Ni(OH)2 recovered from NiOOH on the Ni-based catalyst can be determined by the abundant charge calculated (q) from the reduction peak [78]. The redox peak indicates the ability to accumulate NiOOH, and reflects the molar ratio of generated NiOOH to the total nickel metal loaded on the catalyst. In M-N, the substitution of coordination nitrogen atoms in the components (M= Fe, Ni, Co, etc.) with oxygen, sulfur, or phosphorus has been widely used. Co-doping with multiple heteroatoms to change the electronic structure of the active site is also one of the most effective ways to improve the catalytic activity of metal-free materials [79]. These studies show that the electronic structure takes a great influence on the catalytic activity. So far, this is a huge challenge for the synergies of co-dopants and their corresponding active sites, on the effect of the reaction [80]. The mechanism of urea oxidation is complex because of its six-electron transfer process. Zhang et al. [81] synthesized NiClO-D catalysts via a modified sol-gel technique. The NiClO-D electrode requires a potential of 1.386 V vs.RHE to drive a current density of 50 mA cm−2, and they used DFT, 18O isotope labeling mass spectrometry, and in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) to explore the UOR pathway. The results show that in the UOR process, lattice oxygen preferentially selects the active site of Ni4+ compared with Ni3+, and the kinetic rate is significantly accelerated. Chen et al. [82] proposed an effective electrocatalyst design strategy, which reduces the energy barrier formed by β-Ni(OH)O by regulating the lattice oxygen ligand environment of β-Ni(OH)2 by Co, and thus has good activity in UOR. Moreover, they explored the urea oxidation path by using β-Ni(OH)2 as the model catalyst. They provided conclusive evidence for intramolecular coupling of NN bonds by isotopically labeled in situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), with two N atoms in each N2 molecule formed during the UOR process coming from a single urea molecule. 2.3 Hydrazine oxidation reaction (HzOR) With superior properties such as no noise, high volume energy density, easy to carry and low standard potential value (Eθ = −0.33 V vs. RHE), the hydrazine fuel cell is easy to adapt to military and other special environments [83]. In alkaline environments, the dominant equation for the fuel cell is N2H4 + 4OH−→N2 + 4H2O + 4e−. Obviously, the oxidation products of HzOR are water and N2, which are clean and satisfactory [84,85]. Moreover, HzOR can degrade the harmful hydrazine in wastewater, making HzOR attracted extensive attention instead of oxygen evolution in the production of hydrogen. Modified TMPs has the potential to enhance its catalytic performance for HzOR. It is worth noting that metal doping displays the advantages of controllable doping-amount, simple operation, and short synthesis period. In addition, doping of metal atoms can lead to changes in the inherent properties of excessive metal phosphide, such as increased active specific surface area and optimized electronic structure [86–88]. Therefore, the use of metal doping to metal phosphide has become a common method. So far, both noble metals (Pt, Pd) and non-noble metals (Ni, Co, Cu, Fe) have been explored as electrocatalysts for HzOR [89]. In particular, Ni is characterized by the characteristics of costliness, excellent stability, high electrocatalytic performance, good conductivity and easy preparation [90]. Specifically, Ni-based binary catalysts, such as NiCo, and NiFe, exhibit enhanced electrocatalytic activity and durability compared to mono-metal electrocatalysts because the good synergistic effect [91,92]. It is supposed that introduction of a third heteroatom into the electrocatalyst can restructure the band gap of the material, which is beneficial to improve the activity of the catalyst. P doping has been reported to contribute lone electrons and facilitate the mass transport of catalysts involved in chemical reactions. In addition, P doping can extend the life of the supporter and alter the electron distribution, resulting in high catalytic stability properties [93]. Liang et al. [94] prepared a carbon-borne phosphorus-doped NiCo alloy (NiCoP/C) electrocatalyst in alkaline conditions. The carbon carrier with a large electrochemical surface area is fully in contact with the nanoparticles to accelerate the transfer of the electrons, consequently improving its electrocatalytic performance. Compared with Ni/C and Co/C, NiCoP/C displays high activity with high current density. In addition, NiCoP/C shows small value Tafel slope of 109.17 mV dec−1, low apparent activation energy value (14.66 kJ mol−1) and fast charge transfer rate (Fig. 15 ). It points out the direction for the future development of new non precious metal electrocatalysts. Wang et al. [95] prepared the carbon-borne CuNi catalyst (P-CuxNi/C) using the high-temperature phosphorization process. The P-Cu2Ni/C material shows a high catalytic activity and excellent stability, due to the synergy between Cu, Ni and P. The P-Cu2Ni/C was found to be a diffusion control process of one-way reaction for hydrazine oxidation. This research demonstrates that the synthesized phosphometal catalysts have promising application future for HzOR. Currently, the majority of hydrogen produced through hydroelectrolysis comes from fresh water, which limits the application of the technology in arid regions. Electrolysis of seawater to produce hydrogen is of great significance for saving fresh water resources. As is known, the complex ionic environment of seawater requires great efforts to deal with the interference of negative anion reactions as well as erosion of electrolytic agents and catalysts [96]. Sun et al. [97] made use of a hybrid seawater means for chloride-free H2 by electrolysis related to hydrazine degradation. The researchers designed a self-supported NiCo/Mxene-based catalyst and discovered its hydrazine-assisted seawaterlysis activity in neutral and alkaline seawater electrolytes. The electrolyzer only required an ultra-low voltage of 1.05 V and 0.7 V to achieve a current density of 500 mA cm−2, without producing Cl2/ClO−, and it has greatly avoided the impact of OER. And electrolysis of seawater has been successfully applied to industry to achieve industrial production of hydrogen. Products obtained by UOR and HzOR show low value, but their prospects to reduce severe environmental pollution and water eutrophication dilemmas are good. For example, Wang et al. [98] discovered that there are many advantages by direct electrolysis of animal urine in an alkaline electrolyte. Qiu et al. [90] enables rapid hydrazine degradation of ∼3 ppb residue through HzOR. This proves that UOR and HzOR can be served as a possible urine/hydralide wastewater treatment. These are all typical examples of the utilization of biological wastes. In addition, Ghatak et al. [99,100] have shown the ability to produce hydrogen from black liquor. It's found the effluent from lignocellulosic raw materials for paper-making can be finished at a lower voltage. Hibino et al. [101] discovered that direct electrolysis of non-waste materials as anode reaction has great possibilities, such as paper, breads, cypress chips and rice bran lasting hydrogen preparation. In the near future, there will be various research toward bioassisted electrolytic hydrogen production to achieve more efficient hydrogen production and waste utilization. 2.4 Other small molecules oxidation In addition to small molecule oxidation mentioned in this article, there are some other molecular electrooxidation, such as carbohydrate [102,103], primary amine [104,105] and sulfoxide [106,107]. Liu et al. [102] reported the replacement of OER by electrooxidation of glucose to enhance H2 production. They used a two-electrode electrolyzer with NiFeOx as the anode and NiFeNx as the cathode, which resulted in a high gluconic acid (GRA) yield of 83% at 1.48 V. Zhang et al. [105] synthesized the NiSe electrode by direct selenization of commercially available nickel foam. And they have demonstrated that the electrooxidative conversion of various primary amines to nitrile has high selectivity, high yield, good substrate compatibility and olefinic bond tolerance on the NiSe anode, where Ni2+/Ni3+ can effectively promote its reaction as a active species. Since the electrocatalytic oxidation reactions of primary amines (PAEOR) has a lower theoretical potential than OER, using it as the anode and CoP as the cathode, the battery voltage is significantly reduced relative to the overall water decomposition (for example, a decrease of 210 mV for the benchmark current density of 20 mA cm−2), hydrogen and nitrile can be generated at both the cathode and anode. 3 Problems and prospect Small molecule oxidation is a promising electrochemical strategy to assist water splitting for hydrogen production. Researches have shown that there are many kinds of electro-catalysts for small molecule oxidation. Low-cost non-precious metals, such as nickel and cobalt, have attracted much attention. The influences of the structure and composition of the catalyst on the activity and reaction mechanism of the related reaction are also important scientific topic. In this review, we discussed some EORSM that can replace OER, focusing on small molecule oxidation on BP-based catalysts and TMPs. The EORSM paired with HER not only reduces the electrolytic voltage, but also hinders the production of explosive H2/O2 mixtures and reactive oxygen species. Moreover, EORSM has other advantages. Electrochemical alcohol oxidation can obtain valuable by-products, urea and hydrazine oxidation could reduce wastewater contamination. Electrochemical oxidation of sulfide (H2S) can achieve sulfur recovery and resource utilization of this hazardous waste. The electrochemical oxidative products of glucose such as gluconic acid and glucaric acid are key materials in pharmaceutical industry. Electrochemical oxidation of primary amines could produce nitriles, which are also important intermediate in production of agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and fine chemicals. While hydrogen production through EORSM has gained recognition, there is still a lot of room for progress in its industrial applications. Therefore, we propose the following points we think should be considered in the following scientific studies from the aspect of catalyst design, mechanism study and selectivity at high current density. According to previous studies, designing a good catalyst for EORSM for hydrogen production is still very challenging. So it is very important to gain an insight into the mechanism of the related catalytic reactions and realize the targeted design of the oxidation reaction of each small molecule, thus exploiting the potential catalyst. The rapid and effective screening of catalysts conducive to small molecule oxidation is closely related to its mechanism. Subsequently, the electrocatalytic activity can be improved by regulating the electronic structure of the catalyst. In addition, small molecules mostly have different groups, and an in-depth understanding of the links between various groups and different catalysts can help us quickly find catalysts that are more beneficial to the reaction. Up to now, the mechanism of the oxidation reaction of these small molecules is still controversial. Identifying the active sites of catalysts is critical for deducing the reaction mechanism. However, heterogeneous catalysts always involve several different active sites on the surface, which are difficult to distinguish. In particular, the catalytic active sites are dynamically altered during EORSM under anodic potential. This makes the active sites more difficult to identify. For BP-based catalysts and TMPs, the function of BP and active sites still need to be explored. Therefore, making full use of in situ characterization technology and DFT calculations is essential to analyze the active sites and get the optimal reaction pathway. A comprehensive understanding of the main electrocatalytic reaction mechanism of multiple small molecules can help us effectively grasp the reaction pathway, improve the selectivity of target products, and speed up the development of BP-based catalysts and TMPs for EORSM. For commercial applications, improving its selectivity of the catalyst at high current densities has become a great challenge. The side reaction OER is possibly to compete with EORSM at high current density. To reduce the occurrence of the side reaction OER, preferential adsorption of small molecules is important. In addition, enhancing the contact between reactants and active species is another strategy. This strategy not only facilitates the selection of catalysts but also holds promising commercial prospects. Despite significant progress has been made, current EORSM catalyzed by BP-based catalysts and TMP still mainly focus on directly oxidation of alcohol, urea and hydrazine. Most of these reported oxidation reactions involve multi-electron transfer steps, resulting in lower oxidation kinetics for hydrogen production. Furthermore, electrochemical upgrading from a simple molecular substrate to a more valuable carbon-added molecule has rarely reported. At last, most of the anodic oxidation products are hydrophilic, leading to overoxidation of product with low selectivity and requirement of additional work for product separation from the electrolyte. Therefore, based on BP and TMP catalysts, searching for a diversified more readily oxidized small molecule oxidation reaction to replace OER for producing hydrogen and value-added product with high selectivity, is still demandable. 4 Conclusions In this work, based on these superior properties of BP based nanocomposites and TMPs, such as large specific surface area, strong adsorbability to water, the strong interaction between phosphorus and metals, strong electrical conductivity, etc., the application of BP based nanocomposites and TMPs for EORSM was systematically summarized in the following aspects: (1) Alcohol oxidation; (2) Urea oxidation; (3) Hydrazine oxidation. Moreover, the potential opportunities and challenges for application of BP-based materials and TMPs are also proposed for promoting their development towards electrocatalysis. This work will provide important guidelines for constructing efficient BP-based electrocatalysts and TMPs towards EORSM. coredata.dc:description: The electrochemical oxidation reaction of small molecules (EORSM) has attracted extensive attention due to its advantages such as mild operating conditions, high conversion efficiency, good selectivity and environmental friendliness. Moreover, with relatively fast reaction kinetics and low theoretical thermodynamic equilibrium potential, EORSM is expected to replace anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The coupling of EORSM at anode with hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at cathode could realize multiple targets including high-value chemicals production, pollutant degradation and efficient hydrogen production. Black phosphorus-based nanocomposites are supposed as a promising EORSM electrocatalyst due to their adjustable electronic structure, large specific surface area, high carrier mobility and active lone pair electrons. Apart from that, transition metal phosphates (TMPs) are also widely used for EORSM because of their abundant active sites, strong electrical conductivity and adjustable component structure. This mini review briefly summarizes the recent progress of EORSM including alcohol oxidation, urea oxidation and hydrazine oxidation over BP-based nanocomposites or TMPs. In addition, possible challenges and research directions are also discussed for inspiring people to optimize EORSM using BP-based nanocomposites and ™Ps.
coredata.dc:title: Black phosphorus-based nanocomposites and transition metal phosphates for electrocatalytic oxidation of small molecules
